title: Five things to do in Sydney
text:
Five things to do in Sydney Last updated 05:00, October 5 2015 OzJetBoating Sydney/YouTube 
Jet boating around the Sydney Harbour with OZ Jet boating. 
DRINK WITH A VIEW 
While most visitors flock to Sydney's iconic Opera House for the world-famous art, culture, live performances, history and stunning architecture - the Opera Bar is yet another jewel that can be added to the Opera House's illustrious crown. 
Not only does the Opera Bar offer unbridled views of the glistening Sydney Harbour - and its equally famous Harbour Bridge - it also serves some of the most exquisite and inventive cuisine in town. Being so close to the waters edge it's only natural that the Opera Bar would serve fresh delights straight from the sea. A mouthwatering seafood platter, overflowing with oysters, scallops, king prawns, moreton bay bugs, blue swimmer crab and scampi ceviche, is just one of many the feasts on offer. 123RF 
The Sydney opera house is a must-visit for tourists to the city. 
So what are you waiting for? Grab yourself a "Sydney Sling" cocktail and relax in a place often described as the "best beer garden in the world". 
ZIP ACROSS THE WATER 
If you're looking to experience the sights of Sydney from a different perspective then jump onboard an OZ Jet Boat, but be warned, you will get wet. The boats - nicknamed "Red Sharks" due to their bright red colour - zip around Sydney Harbour, twisting and turning as their experienced drivers perform high-speed manoeuvres. The 30 minute adventure starts in Circular Quay and is the perfect way to see all of Sydney's famous sights, including the Opera House , Clark Island and Shark Island, Taronga Zoo and the Sydney Harbour Bridge . One particular highlight is getting a glimpse of how the other half live as you speed past the luxurious mansions that dot the world-famous harbour. Rides depart on the hour daily from 11am to 4pm. Prices range from A$45 (NZ$50) for a child to A$79 for adults. 
Wallabies player Henry Speight has committed he will play sevens rugby in 2016. 
DRESS UP FOR SEVENS Sydney has been successful in luring Australia's leg of the Sevens World Series from the Gold Coast for the next four years, and Destination New South Wales officials are predicting that the colourful tournament will be a major drawcard for the city. Sydney will be the fourth stop on the extended Sevens World Series circuit in 2015/16, joining the likes of Wellington, Cape Town, Vancouver, Dubai. Paris and London in hosting the two-day event. 
With the likes of All Black stars, Sonny Bill Williams, Liam Messam and Wallaby, Henry Speight, committed to playing the sport this coming season, there is no doubt the Sydney Sevens will attract the same crowds and playful atmosphere as seen in Wellington each year. 
The tournament will be held at Sydney's 45,000-seater Allianz Stadium on 6 and 7 of February, 2016. This years theme is "Go Global" and dressing up - while not compulsory - is always recommended. Single-day tickets for the Sydney Sevens range from A$25 to A$40. Two-day packages start from A$40 to A$70. See rugby.com.au/sydney7s. Ad Feedback 
TAKE A BREAK If you're looking to ditch the hustle bustle of the popular Circular Quay, then why not enjoy a peaceful and scenicferry ride to the beach-side suburb of Manly. While in Manly the most popular attraction is the golden beaches, but there are plenty of other activities and places to explore. Those in relaxation mode can unwind at one of the many waterfront bars and restaurants, or hit the beach and watch some of Australia's epic surfers in action. Home and Away fan? You might want to head along to Palm Beach, the setting for one of Australia's longest-running television programmes. Sydney's famous Manly ferry ride takes approximately 40 minutes and operates from Circular Quay seven days a week. There is also the option of a shorter trip on the Manly Fast Ferry. 
LP's Quality Meats restaurant and bar in Sydney. Image: Supplied 
EAT OUT Sydney has many restaurants - but some of the best are hidden gems tucked away down secluded lanes where you would not expect to find dining at its best. One of these is Firedoor - a restaurant headed by world renowned chef Lennox Hastie. The unexpected restaurant is located on the back streets of Sydney's Surrey Hills and is housed within a historic building that gives it an edgy industrial feel. Inside, the space features an open kitchen, centered around two custom-made wood-fired ovens, four grills and an Aga cooker. The locavore menu is crafted daily, using the best seasonal produce, daily catch from the sea and the best livestock of the land. 
LP's Quality Meats is another beauty tucked away in Sydney's prospering neighbourhood of Chippendale. The family-friendly restaurant is home to the only "South Pride Smoker" in Australia, with the Tennessee made machine creating some of the best smoked and cured meats. The eatery is headed by accomplished chef Luke Powell, and is said to have been inspired by the Stone Barns restaurant in New York, where Powell once worked. The layout, waiters uniforms and general vibe of LP's at times feels more like a local pub than a glitzy restaurant and the meat raffle, held for customers each night, is the icing on the cake. - Stuff
